instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boots, but no trackpad, fan on high.
threads.message: I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board without obvious liquid-damage that boots fine but has no trackpad. Testing with known-good trackpad and cable plugged in. 5V is present going to <CHIP>U5805</CHIP>. Boost circuit is not working. <SIGNAL>Z2_BOOST_EN</SIGNAL> is at 0.043V. The boost circuit area looks clean. <RESISTOR>R5811</RESISTOR> is measuring fine at 100KÎ©. Any thoughts on why <SIGNAL>Z2_BOOST_EN</SIGNAL> is not coming on?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boots, but no trackpad, fan on high.
threads.message:
Firstly trackpad function and trackpad sensor are totally different, even though they both go to the trackpad. You can have a working trackpad with a bad TS0P sensor, and you can have a trackpad that doesn't track but with TS0P sensor working. TS0P sensor failing is what causes fan to be on high.

What is the history of the board? Water, drop, DIY repair? What is diode mode measurement on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5806</RESISTOR>, red probe ground, black probe on pin 2(no power applied of course)? 

This is usually caused from trackpad not being detected sometimes from beat up connector, or <RESISTOR>R5806</RESISTOR> being ripped off by fingernail.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boots, but no trackpad, fan on high.
threads.message: Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5806</RESISTOR> measures fine (0.560) and the whole trackpad circuit area looks good. No physical damage. I removed and reattached <RESISTOR>R5806</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5811</RESISTOR> to make sure there was nothing hiding underneath them.  I was told it was not a spill and I'm 92% sure that's right. Connector looks good.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boots, but no trackpad, fan on high.
threads.message: Check pin 18 and 22 of J5800 for correct voltage.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Boots, but no trackpad, fan on high.
threads.message: Low <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL> enable. Bad <CHIP>U7970</CHIP>. Non-spill fixes are interesting. Somehow missed the fact that <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL> was slightly low. Working fine now. Thanks for the tips.
